facts.text: Civil Appeal No. CV of 1949 filed.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL  Civil Appeal No. CV of 1949  from a Judgment of the Bombay High Court  Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.  dated March 19, 1948, in a reference made by the Income-tax Appel-

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment of Bombay High Court by Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J. dated March 19, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: from a Judgment of the Bombay High Court  Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.  dated March 19, 1948, in a reference made by the Income-tax Appel- late Tribunal under section 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act  Income tax Reference No. 26 of 1947 .

facts.text: Reference made by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act, Income tax Reference No. 26 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: in a reference made by the Income-tax Appel- late Tribunal under section 66  1  of the Indian Income-tax Act  Income tax Reference No. 26 of 1947 . Sir N.P. Engineer  R. J. Kolah, with him  for the appel- lant. C. Setalvad, Attorney General for India,  G. N. Joshi, with him  for the respondent.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 21, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. December 21. The Court delivered Judgment as follows KANIA C.J. -- This is an appeal from a judgment of the High Court at Bombay delivered on a reference by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: Assessees appellants are executors of the will of Mr. J.K. Dubash.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees  appel- lants  are the executors of the will of Mr. J.K. Dubash who died on the 9th of April, 1942, having made his last will on the 8th of April, 1942.

facts.text: Mr. J.K. Dubash died on 9th April 1942.

anchor.surface_text: who died on the 9th of April, 1942, having made his last will on the 8th of April, 1942. Probate of the will was issued to the executors on the 10th of August, 1942.

facts.text: Mr. J.K. Dubash made his last will on 8th April 1942.

anchor.surface_text: having made his last will on the 8th of April, 1942. Probate of the will was issued to the executors on the 10th of August, 1942. During his life- time, the testator carried on the business of shipping agents.

facts.text: Probate of the will issued to executors on 10th August 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Probate of the will was issued to the executors on the 10th of August, 1942. During his life- time, the testator carried on the business of shipping agents. Clause 13 of the will companytains directions about carrying on this business of the testator till its disposal.

facts.text: Testator carried on business of shipping agents during lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: During his life- time, the testator carried on the business of shipping agents. Clause 13 of the will companytains directions about carrying on this business of the testator till its disposal. It directs the executors to carry on the business as a going companycern after his death with power to make fresh companytracts and discharge the existing and future liabilities and all other usual-and necessary powers,

facts.text: Clause 13 of will directs executors to carry on business as going concern after death for up to 12 months, get valuation, sell to nephews if willing, else to third party.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 13 of the will companytains directions about carrying on this business of the testator till its disposal. It directs the executors to carry on the business as a going companycern after his death with power to make fresh companytracts and discharge the existing and future liabilities and all other usual-and necessary powers, unless special circum- stances arose which, in the opinion of the executors, made it expedient to sell the business earlier. This business was to be carried on for a period number exceeding twelve months during which time the executors were to ascertain whether or number any of his nephews was willing to purchase the said undertaking. For this purpose and generally for sale pur- poses, he directed that the executors shall, as soon as possible, after his death, have a valuation made of the said undertak- ing. The undertaking was to be sold so as to include all his interest in the premises, the goodwill, the stock-in- trade, plant, furniture etc. but excluding securities for money and cash in the bank to the credit of the account of that undertaking. If the executors were satisfied before the expiration of one year from the testators death that the said undertaking would number be sold to his nephews be- cause numbere was willing or able to purchase it or if it remained unsold, at the end of a year, to any of the nephews then  whichever event first happened  the executors were directed to sell the undertaking to such third person on such terms and at such price as they thought proper.

facts.text: Business sold to one of the nephews on 1st January 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The business was, so1d to one of the nephews on the 1st of January, 1943. The appellants companytended that within the meaning of section 25  4  of the Indian Income-tax Act the succession to the business took place on the 1st of January, 1943,

facts.text: Appellants contended succession to business took place on 1st January 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytended that within the meaning of section 25  4  of the Indian Income-tax Act the succession to the business took place on the 1st of January, 1943, while the taxing authorities companytended that the succession was on the 9th of April, 1942, when the testator died.

facts.text: Taxing authorities contended succession on 9th April 1942 when testator died.

anchor.surface_text: while the taxing authorities companytended that the succession was on the 9th of April, 1942, when the testator died. The first question submitted for the High Courts opinion related to this dispute.

facts.text: High Court answered first question against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has answered the question against the assessee. In our opinion, the companyclusion of the High Court is companyrect.

facts.text: Second question on amount paid by executors to widow answered against appellants by High Court, not contested in appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The second question referred to the High Court for its opinion was in respect of an amount paid by the executors to the widow of the testator. That question was answered against the appellants by the High Court. Learned companynsel appearing for the appellants intiated that he did number want to companytest the High Courts decision on the point.

facts.text: Appeal limited to first question.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore is limited to the first question only.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds succession took place on death of testator on 9th April 1942.

anchor.surface_text: the date of such succession must be companysidered to be the death of the testator, which was on the 9th of April, 1942. The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Patanjali Sastri J. agrees appeal should be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: PATANJALI SASTRI J.--I agree that this appealshould be rejected.

issues.text: Whether the succession to the business took place on the 1st of January, 1943 or on the 9th of April, 1942, within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contended that within the meaning of section 25  4  of the Indian Income-tax Act the succession to the business took place on the 1st of January, 1943, while the taxing authorities contended that the succession was on the 9th of April, 1942,

issues.text: on what date was the testator, who was carrying on the business of shipping agent and land contractor succeeded in such capacity by another person within the meaning of section 25(4) of the Act--on the 9th April, 1942, when the testator died and the appellants as the executors took over the business and carried it on or on the 1st January, 1943, when the business was sold by them as a going concern ?

anchor.surface_text: The next question is what is the meaning to be at- tributed to the phrase in such capacity? A Full Bench of the Madras High Court in Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income tax.

issues.answer: capacity of a person who carries on the business as the predecessor was carrying it on that is, with a liability to be taxed on its profits and gains

issues.text: whether in respect of the business there is a succession to another person [under section 25(4)]

anchor.surface_text: The only relevant question under sec- tion 25  4  of the Indian Income-tax Act is whether in respect of the business there is a succession to another person. This is a provision to give relief and the scope of the relief must be governed by the words used in the Act.

arguments.claim: In sale/gift/settlement/intestate death, succession occurs on transfer/death date

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed that in the event of a sale or gift of the business by the original owner the succession within the meaning of section 25  4  will take place only on the date of such sale or gift... Similarly in the event of his death intestate his heir-at-law will succeed to the business on the date of his death.

arguments.claim: Executors became assessee liable under ss 3 & 10 on death, effecting succession in such capacity

anchor.surface_text: on the day of the death of the deceased the estate including the business got vested in the executors and the executors carried on the business within the meaning of section 3 read with section 10 of the Act and as such became personally liable as assessee.

arguments.claim: Transfer to trustee effects succession despite no beneficial ownership; same for executors by operation of law

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear that if the testator had transferred the business to a trustee, although the trustees will not be the beneficial owners, in law there will be a succession... there appears no reason why when the legal estate is transferred by operation of law to an executor there should not be considered a succession

arguments.claim: Relief under s25(4) governed strictly by words; succession to another person occurred on death

anchor.surface_text: The only relevant question under section 25  4  of the Indian Income-tax Act is whether in respect of the business there is a succession to another person. arguments.claim: s25(4) consequential on amended s26(2); same meaning of 'succeeded in such capacity'

anchor.surface_text: the enactment of section 25  4  is consequential on the amendment of section 26 2 , and the scope and meaning of the expression succeeded in such capacity by another person in section 26  2  must determine also its scope and meaning in section 25  4 .

holdings.text: The conclusion of the High Court that succession took place on the death of the testator on 9th April 1942 is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has answered the question against the assessee. In our opinion, the conclusion of the High Court is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreeing with High Court; vesting of estate in executors on death who carried on business making them assessee under ss 3 & 10 effects succession under s25(4).

holdings.text: On the day of the testator's death, the estate vested in executors who carried on the business under section 3 read with section 10 becoming personally liable as assessee, effecting succession in such capacity under section 25(4).

anchor.surface_text: on the day of the death of the deceased the estate including the business got vested in the executors and the executors carried on the business within the meaning of section 3 read with section 10 of the Act and as such became personally liable as assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legal estate vests in executors by operation of law; carrying on business imposes personal tax liability changing the assessee.

holdings.text: Date of succession under section 25(4) is the death of the testator on 9th April 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The only relevant question under section 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act is whether in respect of the business there is a succession to another person. This is a provision to give relief and the scope of the relief must be governed by the words used in the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relief provision strictly by words; succession to another person occurred on death as executors took over.

holdings.text: Section 26(2) applies to succession on death, not limited to inter vivos succession.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s24B provides for assessment post-death; proviso (c) to s24(9) implies succession includes inheritance/devolution on death.

holdings.text: 'Succeeded in such capacity' means succeeded in the capacity of carrying on the business with liability to tax on profits, not requiring ownership transfer.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax focuses on carrier of business per s2(2), s10; distinguishes ownership; cites examples like ss 18(7), 42(1); follows Williams v Singer.

holdings.text: Testator succeeded in such capacity by executors on 9th April 1942 as they carried on business as going concern liable under ss 3 & 10.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these principles to the present case... the testator who was carrying on the business in question was succeeded in such capacity by the appellants when the former died on 9th April, 1942.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executors authorized to carry on as going concern; association of persons liable as assessee post-death.

holdings.text: There was succession to the business by another person under section 25(4).

anchor.surface_text: The only relevant question under section 25(4) of the Indian Income-tax Act is whether in respect of the business there is a succession to another person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Executors distinct assessee from testator post-death.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay P.E. Poison 1

anchor.surface_text: the Act of 1922 see Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay P.E. Poison 1 . The relief was, however, confined to discontinued businesses, as, in cases of succession till 1938 the successor alone was assessed to tax on the whole of the profits of the previous year including those earned by his predecessor before the succession occurred. But the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1939,  hereinafter referred to as the amending Act , having amended section 26  2  so as to provide, in the case of a succession in busi- ness, prolession or vocation, for the assessment of the predecessor and the successor, each in respect of his actual share of the profits of the previous year, the relief was extended, by enacting section 25  4 , to cases of succes- sion occurring after the commencement of that Act, with the same object as in the case of discontinuance, namely, to redress the hardship of the business having been Charged twice over on the income of 1921-22.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. P.E. Poison
precedents.cited_proposition: change of the basis of taxation when the Act of 1922 was passed which resulted in the profits of the year 1921-22 being assessed twice over

precedents.citation: Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income tax. Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: A Full Bench of the Madras High Court in Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income tax. Madras 1 , held that the expression meant in the capacity as owner , so that the person who succeeds another must, by such succession, become the owner of the business which his predecessor was carrying on and which he, after the succession, carries on in such capacity, that is. the capacity as owner . Applying that test they held that the sole surviving member of a Hindu undivided family did not succeed to the business of the family within the meaning of section 26 2 , as he was previously a part-owner of the business and there was no transfer of ownership. While it is undoubtedly true that a transfer of ownership is ordi- narily involved in cases of succession falling within sec- tion 26  2  or section 25 4 , it cannot, in my opinion, be regarded as an essential element of succession within the meaning of those provisions.

precedents.case_name: Jupudi Kesava Rao v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression in such capacity meant in the capacity as owner, so that the person who succeeds must become the owner of the business
precedents.cited_holding: sole surviving member of a Hindu undivided family did not succeed to the business of the family within the meaning of section 26(2)

anchor.surface_text: As observed by Lord Cave in Williams v. Singer Others 1  the fact is that, if the Income-tax Acts are examined, it will be found that the person charged with tax is neither the trustee nor the beneficiary as such, but the person in actual receipt and control of the income, which it is sought to reach. There seems to be no warrant, therefore, to insist on a transfer of ownership as the decisive test of succession within the meaning of section 26 2  or section 25 4  any more than for insisting on the ownership of the business by the person carrying on a business, for the purposes of section 10.

precedents.cited_proposition: the person charged with tax is neither the trustee nor the beneficiary as such, but the person in actual receipt and control of the income
